values: This city makes my heart, mind and soul sing.

I've been neglecting LJ for far far too long... although to be honest, I don't see myself using it much anymore... but before I go making everything private, some quick notes on what's been happening in the last year or so: * freelancing since june last year, things are going well. not running out of work, that's for sure. * attended railscamp #1 outside of Sydney in June last year. it. was. awesome. 50 geeks, no internet, lots of chatter, coding, eating, drinking, relaxing and playing guitar hero and wii. * ran railscamp #2 in november last year. just as awesome, and we got to celebrate the election. * heading round the world overseas for four months from the 24th of may. US (Portland, Seattle, New York, Boston, maybe Washington), Canada (Vancouver, Toronto, maybe Calgary, Montreal), UK (London, Edinburgh, Birmingham - for the UK Discworld Con, Cambridge), Germany (Berlin), Turkey (Istanbul), Cambodia (Battambang, Siem Reap, probably Phnom Penh) via Singapore somehow. * nullus #2 is happening in feb next year * pondering organising a UK railscamp. * blogging regularly at http://freelancing-gods.com - and it's not all technical posts * go visit http://www.pangeaday.org - it's such an awesome idea * twittering - http://twitter.com/pat * have applied to talk at RailsConf EU (the visit to Berlin) - won't find out for a while if I get my talk accepted though * Oh, and I have a beard. sorry for my silence. feel free to bug me in comments if you wish.

The wonderful Daniel Knight and Snowgum Films created an amazing opening for the con - absolutely brilliant (not that I'm biased at all). And it's now been put online! w00t! I highly recommend you go watch it - there's several versions to choose from, but I suggest the large Quicktime edition, even if it does take a bit longer to download. Enough of my yabbering, though: Go see!

The convention happened. And it fucking rocked. Even if I didn't have the time to enjoy it properly (apparently I looked like I was on speed on the first day), I still had a wonderful time, and apparently so did a lot of other people (including , , , , , , , , , , , and - damn, I didn't realise I had so many of you on my LJ list). Thanks to everyone for their support, thanks to the committee who did a fantastic job, thanks to all the people who came for making it a ton of fun, thanks to Terry for coming all the way from the UK *and* hinting strongly at a second con (vaguely titled in my head as Nullus Anxietas 2: Rincewind Returns). You all rock. Thank. You. All. So. Much. Cue dramatic flourish And now... I rest. Collapses (Okay, so this post is a bit delayed. A lot delayed. But still, the thanks are no less heartfelt.)

Ok, just a quick note for anyone who likes Discworld and is in Australia in February - as you all know, Nullus Anxietas: The Australian Discworld Convention is happening in Melbourne, and until the end of the year (yes, late notice, I know) there's $20 off convention memberships. If you're thinking of coming along, now is a great time to sign up. So please, go do so. :)

Well, okay, mebbe not the best christmas ever - we've got some young kids here at my parents' for Christmas day... but rain and hail! in the middle of summer, during a serious drought, with water levels extremely low - perfect Christmas present :) Hope you're all enjoying the Christmas break and finding time to relax
My new toy arrived. Yet another distraction from work (only 2 and a half days left at Telstra!)
If you can, consider sending a few dollars to this cause.

Well, I have two weeks left at Telstra, and then Christmas, and then I start at a new job. On Brunswick St, Fitzroy. Coding in Ruby on Rails. For those of you who don't know what that means, it's a hell of a lot closer than Telstra (probably a 15 minute ride), and it's fun code. The company is Square Circle Triangle. Strangely enough, I'm struggling to focus on work at the moment. :)

I want one of these tshirts - but they're out of stock in all men's sizes (yes, I was referring to tshirt sizes in the subject line - why, what did you think I was talking about?). So if *you* would like one, press the 'reprint me?' link, and hopefully there'll be enough potential orders for them to reprint :)
Internet Explorer is completely and utterly fucked. If you want sane web developers, please use Firefox, Opera, Safari, or anything else that isn't Internet Explorer. Thank you.

Ok, time for a public service announcement and favour-asking. As most/all of you on my friends-list know, I'm running Nullus Anxietas, the Australian Discworld Convention, which is happening from the 9th to 11th of February next year. We've got Terry Pratchett coming over for it, and we'll have Stephen Briggs, Bernard Pearson and Colin Smythe available over the internet for video interviews, as well as plenty of other fun stuff happening. The reason I'm bringing this up now is because the membership rates are going up at the end of the month - so if you're interested in coming along, now is a good time to pay up. Also, I'd greatly appreciate it if you could post something to your LJ (like so wonderfully did a few weeks ago), so people who aren't on my friends list are a bit more aware of the price rise and the event. Feel free to direct people to this post, or the website, and I'm more than happy to answer questions people have. Keep in mind, if you want the current rates but can't afford to pay the entire cost right now, you can sign up for a supporting membership ($25), and that'll mean you can sign up at any point and pay the rates that were current when you got the supporting membership. BUT, if you can afford it, please buy a full membership now. More money for us is helpful for things like Venue deposits and Terry's airfare. Oh, one more thing... if you sign up for a full/concession membership (ie. not a supporting one) before the end of the month, you go into the draw for our competition, where the ten winners get to have coffee and a chat with Terry at some point during the convention.

Ok, here's the deal. My sister is currently stuck in Athens, with family of a friend, they speak Greek, not English, she speaks English and not Greek. She's looking for work (without a visa), somewhere in the UK ideally. More importantly, it'd be awesome if we could get her to Manchester by October 19th (her birthday), as friends of our family will be there (parents of a friend of hers) - one of them also has the same day as their birthday. She doesn't want to spend her birthday alone, and spending it with familiar faces would really get her spirits up.

I've already got some very useful links from , and I've found some cheap flights from Athens and Thessaloniki to London, but I'd welcome any other ideas and help. Any suggestions on what could help her survive?

Watch this. No really, watch it. It's not long, but it's one of the brilliant moments of West Wing.

And yay (again) for slick posting from Jabber

very kindly posted an entry yesterday on his lj about Nullus Anxietas, which prompted a bit of discussion - and a lot of it was how it's too expensive.

Obviously, I'm biased, but I just want to point out that it isn't 'expensive' - the price ($160/$140 Concession) is quite normal compared to other such events.

  • The UK Discworld Convention costs something along the line of 60 pounds (I can't confirm, as they've taken prices off their website now that the event is over), which is $150 AUD.
  • Continuum, which happened in August in Melbourne, was $145 in the months leading up to it, then was $175 at the door.
  • Conflux 4 (happening in Canberra next year) is $190 in the last few months leading up to the event, then $220 at the door.

If you're interested in why we have to charge so much (and trust me, if we make a profit, it will be a very very nice surprise - Conventions finish in the red more often than not), here's one of our main costs - Terry's airfare. A flexible business class flight is a bit over $14,000. You could argue he should fly economy - but for health reasons, he actually has to fly first class (and he's covering the upgrade), and as a rule of thumb, Guests of Honour for conventions get business class flights.

Insurance is also a major factor these days - prices are much higher than they were before 9-11.

Just to compare another factor - the UK Convention has very little in the way of venue costs (they're in the middle of nowhere, and so the vast majority of people stay at the hotel, which gives them quite a bit of bargaining power), and their guest costs are dramatically reduced, as all are based in the UK, so flights don't really come into the picture. They also have a geographical advantage - there's a lot more Discworld fans a lot closer to their event.

Conventions don't like charging this much - trust me, we've made every attempt to keep it as cheap as possible - but we also need to break even. I just want to raise awareness that what we're doing isn't expensive, it's just more than first-time convention attendees expect.

I'd welcome comments about any of this...

Reason #n that Textmate is fantastic: Command+Option+. closes the current html tag. So handy, and so annoying that Visual Studio doesn't do the same thing.

Now, if only I had a jabber interface for my blog, then I might post there a bit more often too...
This is a terribly geeky way to post - especially considering I rarely post here anyways, but I just want to see how it works...

Truth (Quicktime movie file)

If you want a bit more in the way of detail, you can see the movie within the context of its webpage.

In other news:

  • I'm back in the office (it's been almost two weeks now) and I'm loving it :)
  • My sister leaves for a Contiki Tour around Europe on Tuesday - and then she'll be working/travelling through most of the countries again, and she's also hoping to spend a few weeks in New York. I'm just a little jealous.
  • And, um... yeah, I think that covers things for the moment.

This morning, I actually woke up on time. That in itself is a rarity. Usually I'll sleep in for quite a while. Had breakfast, showered, etc, then stepped out the door... to find this: and this: and this: and this: It seems to be a mixture of eggs, fish, and some pink fleshy processed meat of some sort (cat or dog food, perhaps). No idea who did it, or why. Cleaned it up, and then arrived at work late. As per usual. So, how was your morning?

For those who I've not already sent the link to: Non Sequitur from last Sunday. For those who aren't familiar with it, it's normally a very clever and very funny newspaper comic strip. The Sunday strips, which as far as I know don't get into newspapers, are always larger and in colour, but the solid and serious point of this one is something different. Pity it won't get the audience that the normal strips do.
There are some strange and dangerous people out there. (Edit: And credit to who sent both links my way)

Yet another short post. Warning: the links below may make you cry, especially if you have children. They will definitely make you sad. Dear Elena - Start from the bottom of the page (or use this link to the first post). Also, a response to the first post. On and off over the last two days, I've been reading this blog, and the comments that others have posted there. I don't know the family in question, but he seems to be well known and well loved amongst tech/entrepreneur circles. It's just so heartbreaking... I don't know what else to say about it.
Happy Birthday to both <lj user="notsomighty"> and <lj user="mrbehemoth"> :)

Just a quick note to those who may be interested - Nullus Anxietas prices will be going up from the 9th of Feb by $40 (from $120 to $160 full, or $100 to $140 concession). So if you're interested in coming along, I highly recommend you sign up before then to get the earlybird rates :)

http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/4642116.stm - it's well and truly official now. Sold for US$7.4 billion. Not a bad profit on the US$10 million Steve Jobs paid for the group when he bought them from George Lucas. The good news:

However, analysts said that the real value to Disney was the talent the deal would bring in-house, especially Pixar executive vice-president John Lasseter, the man credited as being the creative driving force at the firm.

Under the deal, Mr Lasseter will become chief creative officer of the combined animation studios as well as principal creative adviser at Walt Disney Imagineering, the company behind Disney's theme parks.

Disney to buy Pixar Had been rumoured for a while, looks like it's happening. Which, from a larger media perspective, could make things really interesting. From a fan-of-Pixar perspective, is bad news indeed. It *could* turn out well... but I'm not holding my breath.

You must read Neil Gaiman's Anansi Boys (or as my dad calls it, The Gay man's Nancy Boys). Such a brilliant and delightful book. Reminds me a bit of Terry Pratchett's later work - especially the Watch books, but without the dark edge.

I know, I know, it's another short post with a link. But it's just so good, I'm going to share it with you all - altho I know some of you have already read it. Go, peruse the wonders of the Behemoth's travel journal.

An except from erasing.org's Cliffs of Chutney:

...Chutneys! I have never before in my life seen that much chutney beneath one roof. What even is chutney? Dizzying cliffs of chutney, canned and jarred, stacked to the ceiling, churned up from all manner of materials, yet somehow all reducing to that same basic purple-brown snot. Again, egalitarian. Crates of fruit. Barrels of nuts. Fruits that look like nuts. Nuts that look like barrels. How many species of potato does one really require?...

It's a pity the text is all lumped together in one paragraph - makes reading it hard - but it's delightful stuff.
For your viewing pleasure: And for your reading pleasure (ssh, let me have my ego boost): http://blog.freelancing-gods.com/articles/2005/12/13/the-quest-for-content

Ok guys, I need to borrow your collective social networks - I'm looking for people to fit two roles: print designer, and web designer. Although, quite happy to have one person who can do both. I know some of you on my friends list fit those roles, and hey, if you fit the criteria I'm going to list, then let me know. I need these people for the Convention, to design and create graphics and such for any printed documents and/or web sites. The emphasis is on professional work - I won't be accepting even the most hard-core discworld nut if I don't think they're going to produce the level of work I'm looking for - so I want to see a portfolio of some sort - even if it's a bunch of links pointing to sites you've done. To make things a little harder, I'd also prefer the work to be done for free. Yes, I know that's a hell of a lot less tempting, but we're a not-for-profit group, and frankly we can't afford to pay people for design. You don't have to be a Discworld fan, though, but I'd imagine most people who might be interested are probably going to like the books anyways. Now, I'm not expecting this to apply to many people on my friends list - but if anyone knows someone who might fit the bill, I'd massively appreciate you seeing if they'd be interested, or passing me on an email address or url. Also, if any other committee members or other interested parties could link to this post, that'd be awesome. Just to clarify one thing: the web design will be purely design, not back end code. That said, if you want to code as well, I'm not going to complain - makes life easier for and myself. Thanks everyone.

Yes folks, I'm still alive. And I'm kinda up-to-date with all your livejournals - well, except for friends-only posts. Technical reason, don't ask. I may post again soon, but no promises. And I'll try to stay up to date with friends-only posts from here on in. But for now, the two sentence update: At home, sick with a cold, which sucks. Life is very busy, which, while not sucking, is draining.

Too tired and busy at the moment to give a detailed post about Tasmania - still in Hobart, fly back home on Friday, arriving around midday. Might get a post out sometime that day, or maybe over the weekend, or maybe even later. There will be a post tho. In exciting news (for me and perhaps no one else who reads this) Larry Lessig is coming to town - http://www.deakinlectures.com.au/program/m13.php?ref=full *dances*

Paul Hester's death, first brought to my attention by Ben, keeps making me sad whenever I read another blog or news article which talks about it. These ones in particular. I have played some Crowded House today, but it does not help my mood. For something completely different to the above paragraph, I saw Quidam on Thursday afternoon with the family, and it was amazingly awesome. Fun, breath-taking, wonderful music... I know its expensive, but I definitely think its worth it. Cirque Du Soleil are masters of their craft. Screw the traditional circus (which never appealed to me anyways), this is much better. Also seen was a comedy show on Friday with while he temporarily escaped the clutches of Canberra, another on Sunday with my younger brother, and yet another tonight, all by myself. I had organised a group of work peoples to see Danny Bhoy, but unfortunately had two more people confirm after I bought the initial round of tickets. It's general admin (no set seats), so I went to pick up two more on Friday, and found it was sold out. Which made me rather pissed off. Well, extremely pissed off. Anyways, one of the people was quite happy not to come, and I had already given my ticket to the other to give myself incentive to get more tickets asap. I'm seeing Danny Bhoy next week anyways, so it made sense for me to be the one missing out tonight (albeit that I organised the night), and I tried to find someone with an extra ticket, but no luck. I did find a free ticket for a quite average show that was on around the same time, so I saw that instead, then went out for a drink with a couple of those who went to the work show. Leaving for Tasmania on Thursday night next week, getting back on the Friday of the following week. Should be fun - although first family holiday in quite some time, so will be interesting to see how we all get along. Oh, and work is busy. That's enough of an update for the moment.

Since I've just added a few people to my friends list, I guess I should post to make this journal appear to be not quite the dead zone it actually is. And I'm stuck at work at 7pm, waiting for a blasted cube (multi-dimensional database) to compile. Took an hour last run, after some small tweaks it should be less than that this time. Hopefully. But yeah, plenty of time to aimlessly surf the net instead of being productive on various things. Anyways, welcome to , and . I've no idea how long some of you have had me on your friends lists, as I generally read LJ via bloglines - with the occasional browse of the friends page for friends-only posts. Which I'm waaaaay behind on at the moment. Does anyone know a way to get friends-only posts on RSS, perhaps through HTTP Authentication? Super quick update: Work = stressful, Con = a bit stressful, Social Life = surprisingly busy, World of Warcraft = not played enough (or perhaps I'm playing too much as it is). Graduated last week on Wednesday, so that brings a nice feeling of closure to uni, most likely for good. Comedy Festival is almost upon us again, so that should keep the social life kicking. Going to see Cirque Du Soleil's Quidam with the family in two weeks, so looking forward to that (although I miss a staff development afternoon here at work, and they're usually good fun)... Gods, I'm complaining about missing work. Would like to be seeing Ben Folds in early April, but yet to find someone who wants to come and is free on the 6th - so if you do like Ben Folds, and will be in Melbourne on the 6th, please let me know. And after that, there's most likely a trip to Tasmania with the family - altho I'm hesitant to whether the Spirit of Tasmania will already be booked, so it could be postponed yet again (was going to happen in December last year). That'll do for the moment. *Shakes fist at server* Hurry up cube
This will probably mean nothing - at least in the short term - but worth pointing out anyways.

Ye gods, its been ages since I've updated. Mainly due to the usual combination of busyness and laziness. So much to cover, so I'll split it up over a few posts (of varying security levels)... In no particular order I got a new phone yesterday :D - its on a 24 month plan, which isn't good, but its a damn good phone, so that makes up for it. The reason for getting it is because my old phone decided to only respond to about 1 in 100 key presses (so I'd be lucky to start it up, let alone key my pin in, and there's probably a few sms's on there I wasn't able to read). I moved out of my place in Abbotsford on the weekend before Christmas, then found a new place on Tuesday, so started moving stuff in the Monday after Christmas. I'm still at my folks at the moment (which is where I've resided since leaving Abbotsford), but I'll prob get everything in my room sorted over the next few days and be in by the start of next week. We've only had the power and phone on since today, and gas isn't officially on until next Wednesday, but it works. My brother is spending his first night there tonight. Yes, for those who didn't know, I'm moving out with my brother. It shall be interesting (as I've said many a time, since I'm using that as my default statement). Oh, and since it doesn't look like I've mentioned it before on here, the reason I moved out of the Abbotsford place was because one housemate was only planning to stay for a few months, and is going to Canberra for a year (he chooses to go to Canberra - something ain't right in his head ;). So I ran out of housemates, and about the only person I could find that was interested was my middle brother. The one who is not at all like me. To jump to another topic completely, I passed all my uni subjects. Granted, the group project mark wasn't nearly as high as I was expecting, but it doesn't matter all that much - except one of our group members failed, and now I've got both him and his father asking me to somehow convince the subject convener to pass him. Christmas day was spent with the family, nice and relaxed, which is the usual, and its much preferred to going out and visiting relatives like some people do. Tonight was even more quiet, since it seemed everyone else I usually spend new years with are either interstate, or going to a rave, or had other plans. I don't have the money to throw around on a flight, nor do I like drugs and dance/techno/[whatever its called now] music, and I prefer parties where I know more than one person. Yes, I am an introvert. So I spent the night by a fan, usually playing World of Warcraft, or chatting with my parents. Went up to the nearby park which has a nice hill for viewing fireworks all around the city - we even had a local not-quite-legal display going there. I tried to get some photos with my phone, but I generally mistimed it. If I can be bothered, I might post some of the better pictures. More posts soon? Maybe.

I forgot Katie's birthday! *hangs head in shame* I'm sorry. I hope you had a fantastic day. Other random LJer comments... - I like your plans for NYE. I must try and be in Germany around the New Year sometime. - Thanks for the work on the convention site. One less thing I have to stress about. - Welcome back. Looking forward to tales of your trip to Europe (or any other tales you write - always enjoyable). - Good to hear you're enjoying your time back in Germany. - Hope you're surviving okay without Internet - I think I'll be facing that situation myself over the next two weeks (at least, when I'm at my new place) because I'm not expecting a quick connection for my new dsl account. - Have fun in Canberra (sucker!) ;) And to all - I hope you had a great Christmas, and had/having fun on New Years.
If Only Yes, its a hoax. Altho, Google News fell for it :D
We are now LIVE! For any of you wanting to buy your membership for Nullus Anxietas: The Australian Discworld Convention, there is a form awaiting your details here. Go on, you know you want to ;)

Fucking Howard Government: Australia may have "innocently" exported nuclear technology to parties with weapons of mass destruction (WMD) programs, Defence Minister Robert Hill said today. Aust admits possible WMD breach

It turns out it was Kind of Pluto's last gig for the year, not forever! The misunderstandings (and well, it was never clear) were due to a misprint in one of the major street mags, and Gatesy being a tosser. Altho, its a well known fact that everyone's a tosser ;) And they played Car Crash, which always makes my hair stand on end... just a pity there's no recording of it available yet. So its a nice happy night - tho I'll be a walking zombie at work tomorrow.
